node.text:
Learn how to work some Worn Wear magic—from home. We’ve got some tips on how to fix
your gear with what you’ve got. Head on over to @wornwear to see the latest repair tutorials. 

Video: @reunion_originals @kernducote
#fixitfromhome #wornwear

node.title: Worn Wear: Fix It From Home

node.text: Since 1973, we’ve built clothes to endure, so you don’t need to buy new as often. There are some things you can do, too. Buy less. Buy used. Repair what you wear out. Demand recycled. Demand Fair Trade. Demand organic. You have the power to change the way clothes are made. Click the link in bio for more. #buyless #demandmore

Today, despite support from voters across the political spectrum, our public lands face unprecedented threats from extractive industries and the politicians in their pockets. Part love letter, part political exposé, Public Trust investigates how we arrived at this precarious moment through three heated conflicts—a national monument in the Utah desert, a mine in the Boundary Waters, and oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge—and makes a case for the continued protection of public lands.

@PublicTrustFilm produced by Jeremy Rubingh @jeremycoloradoboy and directed David Byars @byars_remorse

node.text: Regenerative Organic agriculture could be a viable way to help stop climate change before it's too late. In 1996, Patagonia decided to exclusively use organic cotton and recycled cotton. Now we’re taking our commitment even further by growing the cotton in our clothes with Regenerative Organic methods. The highest organic standard, this farming method supports people and animals working together to restore the health of our planet to create a brighter future.

node.title: Why Regenerative Organic?  Part 3: What We’re Doing (and Why)​

node.text: Because healthy soil traps carbon, many believe that Regenerative Organic farming methods have the potential to change the way we grow food and fiber and restore the health of our soil and climate. These practices help build healthy soil that could help draw down more carbon from the atmosphere than conventional methods.

node.title: Why Regenerative Organic?  Part 2: Soil Is the Solution​

Sometimes you get lucky. After the snowiest winter in a decade in Iceland’s Westfjords, @camillaiceland arrived on the first clear day in nearly a month. She shook off her jetlag and dropped into this sunset line above a tiny fishing village, then hopped on a sailboat for a three-week trip. A great way to prep the sea legs, indeed. ⁠
Photo: @marykmcintyre

node.text:
Parenting advice is everywhere; valuable parenting advice is rare. Writer Aimee Eaton shares her mud-caked and messy observations on raising children to be planet-loving activists. “First, stomp in puddles. Lay in the grass. Catch frogs, trout and lightning bugs. Get curious. Fall madly, wildly in love with being in the world. Then do the work to protect it. Fill the cup, then let it pour over.”—Aimee Eaton⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Read “Be Brave. Be Kind. Go Get ‘Em!” through the link in bio.⁠⁠
Photo: Jeremiah Watt / @miahwatt⁠⁠
@patagonia_flyfish

Comics journalist @sarahmirk visits donation centers like @join_pdx @raphaelhousepdx and @blanchethouse to learn the dos and don'ts of donating clothes with dignity. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
“During the pandemic, I stopped wearing about 90% of my clothes—especially my ’professional’ outfits ... At first, I traded in my ’professional pants’ with @wornwear and then donated a bunch of clothes to thrift stores. But then I began to wonder if there was a way to donate directly to people in need ... Many shelters in my city, Portland, Oregon, also take clothing donations. But they don’t want to be burdened with donations that aren’t clean or useful.“

node.text:
What does it take to save a watershed?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The Maipo River Valley provides most of the water supply for the city of Santiago, Chile, home to more than 7 million people. But it’s currently threatened by the Alto Maipo hydropower project. Local trail runner Felipe Cancino runs 120 kilometers with over 5,800 meters of gain to trace the route of the Alto Maipo pipelines. Through this traverse, Felipe reveals how the project is altering the course of the river, causing small towns and traditions to disappear, endangering Santiago’s water supply and forever impacting the natural environment of this valley.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
This film shows us the true value of this ecosystem and the high costs of the country’s development system. Will Chile choose a different path? �⁠⁠
Follow the link in bio to watch the film: Corriendo Para Salvar Una Cuenca | Run To Save a Watershed⁠⁠

node.text:
Run to: A film series about runners finding activism through sport.⁠
⁠
We’ve been runners for 2 million years. We ran to hunt antelope, deliver messages or move from place to place as quickly as possible. Monks in Japan still run laps around a mountain in pursuit of enlightenment. Children (and adults) around the world run for the simple enjoyment of it. We can run away, toward, from, to, up, down, with, or simply run. The act is practical and spiritual, all at once. Few other ways of moving offer such diversity and utility.⁠
⁠
But running is also a powerful tool for activism. The act of traversing massive tracts of the planet’s most beautiful landscapes connects us more deeply to the places we run, reminds us of the importance of access, and impels us to stand up and fight when these places and communities are threatened. ⁠
⁠
Follow the link in bio to watch the first episode: Corriendo Para Salvar Una Cuenca | Run To Save a Watershed⁠

node.text:
In the foothills of the Patagonian Andes, Chilean mountain biker Gabo Benoit @gabobenoit is working to replace a history of resource extraction with a community-based recreation economy, one trail at a time.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Listen to the interview with Gabo (or read the transcript) through the link in bio.⁠⁠
Photo: Martin Garcia de la Huerta / @martingarciadelahuerta⁠⁠
 @patagoniachile

node.text:
Sam DeNicola doesn’t consider himself a great baker or a cyclist. So why did he join his friends to start Bread Bike, a bicycle-delivery breadmaking business in San Luis Obispo, California? His reasons are deliciously unexpected.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Read the story through the link in bio.⁠⁠
Photos: Joe Haeberle / @josephhaeberle⁠⁠
@patagonia_workwear
